title: From Mumbai To Paris, Protesters Are In Streets With A Clarion Call To Act Now And Save Earth
text:
Never before in the history of mankind climate change was considered a threat as big as it is now. Across the globe, people are coming to terms with the fact that global warming and consequent climate change is an inevitable reality with dire consequences for the survival of mankind.

Looking up to world leaders is deemed inconsequential as prosperity is only weighed in terms of wealth, capital and development. But it comes at the cost of the planet, which has been ignored for long.

In the past 50 years, over 26 billion species of birds have been destroyed.

Our ecological system is interconnected and when we destroy one part, repercussions are bound to be seen in different parts too.

If we don’t stop exploiting our planet now, the day is not far when our it won’t be able to support human life. Our oceans are already choked and dying. Our air is unbreathable. Our land is full of garbage and buildings.

And one fact remains -- there is no Planet B.

Over the years, protests to save the planet have assumed massive shape and significance. All across the world, rallies are protests have been organised to wake up our leaders from slumber and urging them to act not to save Earth.

Protests in Mumbai to save Aarey Forest

People in Mumbai, Maharashtra have been protesting the construction of proposed metro car shed in Aarey Forest, the remaining green patch amidst the concrete jungle of the financial capital.

Mumbai's Aarey Colony is at the centre of a heated debate on environment vs development as the authorities went ahead with the decision to cut trees. The forest is spread over an area of 13,000 hectares and is home to 27 Adivasi villages and inhabits various animal species.

Residents and environmental activists opposed the cutting of trees and have been protesting for weeks. Things took an ugly turn when authorities entered the forest and started cutting trees, with police arresting 29 activists and detaining 55 others in connection with the protests.

Paris Climate Change protests

Hundreds of climate activists barricaded themselves into a shopping complex ahead of a planned series of protests by the Extinction Rebellion movement.

Campaigners faced off against police and some shoppers as they occupied part of the Italie 2 mall in southeast Paris all day yesterday, staying put into the early hours of this morning, reported The Journal.

AP

They unfurled banners with slogans like "Burn capitalism not petrol" above restaurants and the window displays fashion boutiques.

According to a report by AFP, the protest comes ahead of planned disruption to 60 cities around the world from Monday in a fortnight of civil disobedience, from Extinction Rebellion (XR), which is warning of an environmental "apocalypse".

Delhi -- Citizen's declare climate crisis and die-in

On October 6, residents of Delhi are set to take part in a die-in: a demonstration where people lie down as if dead, to raise awareness about how fatal and dire our future looks like.

The event is hosted by Extinction Rebellion - Delhi, an international movement that uses non-violent civil disobedience to stop the risk of human extinction and ecological collapse.

The aim is to bring together everyone who wants to save the common future for all, getting the government to act on the climate and catastrophe.

School strike for the climate

The school strike for the climate also known variously as Fridays for Future (FFF), Youth for Climate, Climate Strike, Youth Strike for Climate, is an international movement of school students who skip classes to participate in demonstrations to demand action to prevent further global warming and climate change.

Likely the largest climate strikes in world history, the 20 September strikes gathered roughly 4 million protesters, many of them schoolchildren, including 1.4 million people on strike in Germany.

Reuters

These strikes and demonstrations are just a way to tell leaders to act now. No matter where these protests take place, the overall message is unified - a powerful demand for an urgent step-change in action to cut emissions and stabilise the climate.

Nations around the world agreed at a 2015 summit in Paris to hold warming to less than 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 Fahrenheit) more than pre-industrial-era levels by the end of this century.

But US President Donald Trump subsequently announced that he was withdrawing the US from the agreement, which he said benefited other nations at the expense of American businesses and taxpayers.
